description:
This is the pull request in response to [Issue #1055](https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/issues/1055/ramses-units-error-with-boxlen-1)

I have updated which units get multiplied by a factor of boxlen for the ramses frontend. 

The current consensus emerged from the discussion in the Issue thread, as well as by comparing the results produced by yt to those produced by pymses. As of now, both are consistent.

Only the length unit gets multiplied by a factor of boxlength. It is important to do this right at the end of the unit assignment as otherwise the boxlen factor can get accidentally folded into derived units, such as the pressure or temperature unit. 

All other units are taken are as they are in the info file.

One difference between pymses and yt remains: In yt, the density unit used to calculate the temperature is multiplied by a mean_molecular_weight_factor, currently hardcoded to 0.76. This is not done in pymses, and leads to a difference between the two.
Any thoughts on why/if this is correct are greatly appreciated. 

Thank you,
Ricarda


* fixed units for ramses with boxlen not equal to 1
* fixed ramses units for boxlen not equal to 1
* added comments to ramses unit calculation
title: Fixing units for ramses when boxlen>1.

pullrequest.title: Fixing units for ramses when boxlen>1.

content.raw: pymses omits the factor of mean_molecular_weight_factor when calculating this unit.
content.html: pymses omits the factor of mean_molecular_weight_factor when calculating this unit.

pullrequest.title: Fixing units for ramses when boxlen>1.

content.raw:
The factor of mean molecular weight is coming from the definition of temperature for an ideal gas. Whether or not to include it should probably depend on whether or not Ramses includes it internally when calculating temperatures for e.g. cooling rates.

Do you have any ramses datasets that have boxlen != 1? If so, can we include it in the answer testing suite so this can't break again in the future?
content.html:
The factor of mean molecular weight is coming from the definition of temperature for an ideal gas. Whether or not to include it should probably depend on whether or not Ramses includes it internally when calculating temperatures for e.g. cooling rates.

Do you have any ramses datasets that have boxlen != 1? If so, can we include it in the answer testing suite so this can't break again in the future?

pullrequest.title: Fixing units for ramses when boxlen>1.

content.raw: RAMSES has indeed historically not included the mean molecular weight in its units. I'm not sure why. One thing to be aware of is that the mean particle mass can change with the ionisation fraction, so this is worth bearing in mind. Anyway, in my code I correct for the mean molecular mass, and I vaguely remember discussing this with the pymses people, will bring it up again with them.
content.html: RAMSES has indeed historically not included the mean molecular weight in its units. I'm not sure why. One thing to be aware of is that the mean particle mass can change with the ionisation fraction, so this is worth bearing in mind. Anyway, in my code I correct for the mean molecular mass, and I vaguely remember discussing this with the pymses people, will bring it up again with them.

pullrequest.title: Fixing units for ramses when boxlen>1.
Fixing units for ramses when boxlen>1.

content.raw: I had a look through the code and it does indeed seem to me that the mean molecular mass needs to be folded into the units. RAMSES seems to handle it separately and usually calculates it, except in a few spots where it seems hardcoded to 0.76, just like in yt.
content.html: I had a look through the code and it does indeed seem to me that the mean molecular mass needs to be folded into the units. RAMSES seems to handle it separately and usually calculates it, except in a few spots where it seems hardcoded to 0.76, just like in yt.

pullrequest.title: Fixing units for ramses when boxlen>1.

content.raw:
Even one without particles would be helpful.

Take a look at `yt/frontends/ramses/tests/test_outputs.py`. There are already some answer tests there using the `output_00080` dataset (see the `test_output_00080` function).

You'll also need to make the dataset public, so we can add it to http://yt-project.org/data. You could either put it up on a public webpage, share a google drive or dropbox download link, or upload the dataset to storage we have here at NCSA using the following command:

```bash
curl -T thefile.tar.gz http://use.yt/upload/
```

Once that finishes, it will print out a link that you can use to share the dataset publicly.

One the test has been added and the dataset has been made public, @xarthisius will set up testing on our test bot and we will merge the pull request.
content.html:
Even one without particles would be helpful.

Take a look at yt/frontends/ramses/tests/test_outputs.py. There are already some answer tests there using the output_00080 dataset (see the test_output_00080 function).

You'll also need to make the dataset public, so we can add it to http://yt-project.org/data. You could either put it up on a public webpage, share a google drive or dropbox download link, or upload the dataset to storage we have here at NCSA using the following command:

curl -T thefile.tar.gz http://use.yt/upload/

Once that finishes, it will print out a link that you can use to share the dataset publicly.

One the test has been added and the dataset has been made public, Kacper Kowalik will set up testing on our test bot and we will merge the pull request.

pullrequest.title: Fixing units for ramses when boxlen>1.

content.raw:
I tested this pull request on a ramses dataset of my own, and I can confirm that the particles' positions are indeed right now. Before they were larger by a factor boxlen^2, apparently.

One odd thing is that my ds.length_unit is equal to boxlen now, instead of the length unit. I don't know if this is intentional or not.
content.html:
I tested this pull request on a ramses dataset of my own, and I can confirm that the particles' positions are indeed right now. Before they were larger by a factor boxlen^2, apparently.

One odd thing is that my ds.length_unit is equal to boxlen now, instead of the length unit. I don't know if this is intentional or not.

pullrequest.title: Fixing units for ramses when boxlen>1.

content.raw:
Hi Rafael, 
Is this what you are getting too?
![Screen Shot 2015-08-14 at 17.34.31.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/2745354899-Screen%20Shot%202015-08-14%20at%2017.34.31.png)

If so, then that was indeed intentional. The idea is that if you take a position in code units, say [0.5,0.5,0.5] and multiply it by the length_unit, you get the position in the box, without having to think about the factor of boxlen.

All the best and thanks for checking,
Ricarda
content.html:
Hi Rafael, Is this what you are getting too?

If so, then that was indeed intentional. The idea is that if you take a position in code units, say [0.5,0.5,0.5] and multiply it by the length_unit, you get the position in the box, without having to think about the factor of boxlen.

All the best and thanks for checking, Ricarda

pullrequest.title: Fixing units for ramses when boxlen>1.

content.raw:
My results are consistent with yours (although with different numerical values). ds.parameters['unit_l'] gives 1 kpc, as expected from my user units.

Everything seems right, then.
content.html:
My results are consistent with yours (although with different numerical values). ds.parameters['unit_l'] gives 1 kpc, as expected from my user units.

Everything seems right, then.

pullrequest.title: Fixing units for ramses when boxlen>1.

content.raw:
Hi everyone,
I can confirm you that, in PyMSES, the temperature unit has always been set, by choice, to be the unit for T/mu where mu is the mean molecular weight (following R. Teyssier advice on the subject, since the exact same operation is performed in different places within Ramses)

Hope that clears any doubt.

Feel free to contact me if you need to discuss something about PyMSES/Ramses.
content.html:
Hi everyone, I can confirm you that, in PyMSES, the temperature unit has always been set, by choice, to be the unit for T/mu where mu is the mean molecular weight (following R. Teyssier advice on the subject, since the exact same operation is performed in different places within Ramses)

Hope that clears any doubt.

Feel free to contact me if you need to discuss something about PyMSES/Ramses.
